info.game_comments:
2001 Teen Tournament final game 1.
From the Pennsylvania Convention Center in Philadelphia.

(1, 1).clue: In 1806 he published his first lexicographical work, "A Compendious Dictionary of the English Language"

(2, 1).clue: Michael Jordan & the Looney Toons play basketball to win their freedom from alien slavers in this 1996 movie

(3, 1).clue: The Creative Labs Nomad Jukebox can store over 100 hours of music in this popular format

(4, 1).clue: The name of this breed seen here can also mean a person who's a determined pursuer

(5, 1).clue: The Douglas type of this 3-letter tree is the state tree of Oregon

(6, 1).clue: In 1990 this future Mrs. Alec Baldwin & investors paid $20 million for a GA. town; they sold it in '95 for $4.3 million

(1, 2).clue: In October 1804 Lewis & Clark prepared to spend the first winter of their trip near this present-day N.D. capital

(2, 2).clue: This singer played center fielder Mae Mordabito in "A League of Their Own"

(3, 2).clue: You have to "hand" it to this brand seen here; it's organizing the world

(4, 2).clue: This term for a small dog held on a seated person's legs also applies to a man who does others' bidding

(5, 2).clue: Rhode Island picked the "red" type of this tree; Vermont got the "sugar" kind

(6, 2).clue: To know this singer raised in Star, Mississippi, "Breathe" & have faith

(1, 3).clue: In 1801 Thomas Young found the cause of astigmatism & demonstrated the wave theory of this

(2, 3).clue: In 1995's "The Big Green", an underdog team learns to excel at this sport

(3, 3).clue: This company's I-Zone comes in a color called phat blue

(4, 3).clue: The type of dog seen here, or a tool used in lectures

(5, 3).clue: Delaware chose a type of this tree that's paired with "the ivy" in a Christmas song

(6, 3).clue: Born in D.C. in 1948 but later calling Tennessee home, she nearly became first lady in 2001

(1, 4).clue: In 1804, under Dessalines, this island nation proclaimed itself the first black republic

(2, 4).clue: This 1992 film spawned 2 sequels & an NHL team

(3, 4).clue: The Philips DSR6000 combines a DirecTV receiver with this brand's TV recording system

(4, 4).clue: According to the AKC, a poodle can be no taller than 10" to compete as this type

(5, 4).clue: When I think of this state tree of Texas, I get hungry for pralines

(6, 4).clue: Born in Miami in 1938, she was the first woman appointed U.S. attorney general

(1, 5).clue: On August 3, 1807 his treason trial began in Virginia; he was acquitted on September 1

(2, 5).clue: This movie about a hoop-shooting hound was followed by a sequel subtitled "Golden Receiver"

(3, 5).clue: The device seen here, it wirelessly connects your Apples

(4, 5).clue: You could say, "You're the dog now, man" to King Charles II, for whom a small breed of this dog was named

(5, 5).clue: I'd like to dance the Charleston under this Palmetto State's state tree, the palmetto

(6, 5).clue: Born in Tuscumbia, Alabama on June 27, 1880, she lost her sight & hearing by age 1 1/2

(1, 1).clue: Lying on the east bank of the Nile, Tahrir Square is the center of this capital's downtown

(2, 1).clue: "I'd rather be dead than singing Satisfaction when I'm 45", said this band's Mr. Jagger, grandfather of 2

(3, 1).clue: Sonya is a kittenish 15-year-old introduced in book 1 of this long Tolstoy novel

(4, 1).clue: Before TV, CBS started in this medium

(5, 1).clue: In the 1600s William Harvey dissected Sir Froggie to write "On the Motion of the Heart and" this substance

(6, 1).clue: Spelled one way, it's a strong ache; spelled another, a sheet of glass in a window

(1, 2).clue: This Algerian port's old city is dominated by the Casbah

(2, 2).clue: JFK was president when this California band hit the charts for the first time with "Surfin' Safari"

(3, 2).clue: In "Out of the Dust", Billie Jo relates the story of life in this state's Panhandle during the Dust Bowl years

(4, 2).clue: Gratuitous violence isn't seen on this network, so Oscar won't be beating the stuffing out of Grover

(5, 2).clue: In Froggie's skull, you'll find the olfactory nerve that helped him smell & this main nerve that helped him see

(6, 2).clue: The name of this cap worn on graduation sounds like something used by bricklayers

(1, 3).clue: The first recorded eruption of this Sicilian volcano occurred in about 1500 B.C.

(2, 3).clue: These rockers led by Steven Tyler have been together (on & off) for 31 years

(3, 3).clue: The 5-letter title of this 1999 novel refers to what Melinda, the traumatized heroine, is unable to do

(4, 3).clue: Since 1996 the Walt Disney Company has owned this "Alphabet Network"

(5, 3).clue: Type of "cord" & (in males only) of "sac" that lets the frog croak

(6, 3).clue: The 2-letter term for a medical prescription; it also means a remedy or cure

(1, 4).clue: The westernmost of Canada's prairie provinces, it produces most of the country's crude oil & natural gas

(2, 4).clue: 'N Sync's Justin Timberlake was born in 1981, 10 years after this band's Jim Morrison died

(3, 4).clue: A shy teenager named Charlie is the hero of "The Perks of Being" this kind of "flower"

(4, 4).clue: In July 2000 this network announced that the "United" in its name would get a smackdown

(5, 4).clue: This tube leading from mouth to stomach is where flies pass through after Froggie catches them

(6, 4).clue: Add 1 letter to a timepiece to get this word for a sample piece of cloth (it's also a brand of timepiece)

(1, 5).clue: This "saintly" island of Napoleon's death was named for Constantine the Great's mother

(2, 5).clue: He's the teen heard here in a song released just months before his death"Para bailar la bamba, para bailar la bamba, se necesita una..."

(3, 5).clue: This novel tells us that 16-year-old Esmeralda can dance with rotating swords balanced on her forehead

(4, 5).clue: This network isn't named for an animal, but for a businessman who died in 1952

(5, 5).clue: You'll note that the frog's heart has 2 atria, like yours, but just 1 of this chamber

(6, 5).clue: This 5-letter prefix meaning "sun" can precede centric or sphere

(0, 0).clue: In 1850 it was the name of the party of the British prime minister & of the U.S. president
